2. A 5-year-old girl is referred to the pediatric neurology department due to progressive coordination difficulties and frequent falls over the past year. Her parents report nystagmus that was first noticed in infancy, along with delayed speech development and increasing muscle stiffness. She achieved early milestones such as sitting and crawling but began to regress, showing signs of spasticity and ataxia. There is no consanguinity in the family, but an older maternal cousin exhibited similar symptoms and passed away in early childhood. Neurological examination reveals pendular nystagmus, hyperreflexia, and a spastic gait with scissoring. Brain MRI shows diffuse hypomyelination affecting the cerebral white matter and corpus callosum. Genetic analysis identifies a duplication mutation in the PLP1 gene, confirming Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease. A multidisciplinary team initiates physiotherapy, nutritional support, and symptomatic management aiming to improve her quality of life.

ANSWER: Well, my daughter is 5 and she’s been having a really hard time with walking and stuff. She keeps falling, and she’s always been a bit wobbly with her eyes, but now it’s worse and she can’t really talk right. We’re just worried because she’s not acting like herself and we don’t know what’s wrong.
